transcript.text: Your turn to demonstrate you know how to apply the trade compliance rules. Connect each situation on the left to the correct solution on the right and click Submit.

contentText.text: Demonstrate you know what to do in each of these situations.

instructionText.text: Select an item from the first column, then drag the arrows to its matching solution in the second. When you're done, click on submit.
Click on the question marks to learn more.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

tab.text: You are heading to Beijing for business. A colleague asks you to bring a product sample to a contact there.
You are a UK citizen visiting customers in the EU. You meet a distributor who is a Syrian national and he asks to have a product sample.
A customer representative from Saudi Arabia calls with questions about the test protocol and design technology of one of our products.
Your team collaborates with a global customer using OneDrive. The project manager asks you to upload technical information since he’s not allowed to send a hard copy to the customer’s country.
Check to see if this is permitted and if you need a license before proceeding

correct.text: That’s it – you’ve matched them all correctly.

incorrect.text: That’s not correct. Now click on each solution again to learn more.

optfeedback.text: If permitted, in this situation it would be best to ship the sample in advance. If you are permitted by trade personnel to hand-carry, you should properly disclose to customs what you are carrying when you exit and enter the country.
You can’t share a product sample with someone from a sanctioned country such as Syria, so in this situation you must politely refuse.
You need more information before you can share this information. Double check with trade compliance experts whether this information can be shared with this person.
You should decline the request. If you are not allowed to export the physical version of a document, the same restrictions apply to an electronic version of that same document.
